title: Hawa Mahal
summary: The Hawa Mahal, also known as the “Palace of Winds,” is a unique five-story palace located in Jaipur, Rajasthan, India. Built in 1799 by Maharaja Sawai Pratap Singh and designed by Lal Chand Ustad, it is constructed from red and pink sandstone. Its distinct honeycomb-like exterior features 953 intricately latticed small windows (Jharokhas). The palace's original intent was to allow royal ladies to observe street life and festivals without being seen, while also facilitating cool air circulation through the Venturi effect during hot summers. A significant renovation occurred in 2006, and it is currently a popular tourist spot, maintained by entities like the Unit Trust of India.

current_status: The Hawa Mahal is a well-preserved historical monument and a prominent tourist destination in Jaipur. It underwent significant renovation in 2006 and continues to be maintained by corporate sector involvement, such as the Unit Trust of India. It is an integral part of the City Palace complex.
future_prospects: Future prospects for the Hawa Mahal likely include its continued preservation as a historical and cultural monument, ongoing maintenance efforts to ensure its structural integrity, and its sustained role as a major tourist attraction for both domestic and international visitors. There may be further initiatives for heritage promotion and visitor experience enhancement.
